results.title: Boys Town
results.creator_credit: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Loews Inc, John W. Considine and Norman Taurog
results.brief_description: The moving story of Father Flanagan (Spencer Tracy) who battled the courts, the community but mostly the odds to build Boys Town in Nebraska, a home for abandoned, homeless boys, regardless of race, creed or colour. When the tough, rebellious Whitey March (Mickey Rooney) arrives, Father Flanagan faces the challenge of his life. He must fight not only to save the self-destructive youth, but to save Boys Town itself. Spencer Tracy won his second Academy Award for his performance and Mickey Rooney excels as Whitey, proving his strength as a talented dramatic actor. Eleanore Griffin and Dore Schary also earned Oscars for their original story. Co-starring Henry Hull, Leslie Fenton and Gene Reynolds. “Boys Town” will steal your heart and leave you with something even better - inspiration.

results.title: Boys on the side
results.creator_credit: Studio Canal+, Regency Enterprises, Alcor Films, New Regency Pictures, Heva Productions, Monarchy Enterprises B. V., Arnon Mitchell, Steven Reuther, Herbert Ross and Ken Adam
results.brief_description: Three women share a car going West and laughs, tears and togetherness unfold along the way. They each have secrets to reveal, strengths to impart and vital moments of self discovery; and their shared friendship subsequently becomes family. Whoopi Goldberg (a wisecracking, lesbian club singer), Mary Louise Parker (a finicky HIV+ real-estate agent) and Drew Barrymore (a free spirit) join forces in this celebration of camaraderie, the art of survival, the gift of laughter and the miracle of friendship and caring by Herbert Ross, the director of The Turning Point and Steel Magnolias. Co-starring Matthew McConaughey, James Remar, Billy Wirth, Anita Gillette, Dennis Boutsikaris, Amy Acquino, Stan Egi and Estelle Parsons.

results.title: Boys on film 3: Beyond gravity. Bad news bachelors. Resonance
results.creator_credit: Realworld Pictures, Resonance Films and James Wallace Productions
results.brief_description: Three short films from Australia and New Zealand featuring gay male characters. “Bad news bachelors” Set in Sydney, this short film follows thirty-something Stuart as he roams the city’s cafes, bars and cruising areas looking for a man to love but finding only sex with a series of likeable men - none of whom offer the likelihood of a relationship. “Resonance” This short experimental dance film opens with a vicious gay bashing, then pieces together the relationship between the victim, the basher and his girlfriend. Homophobia and misogyny are linked in the character of the basher. The plot is deliberately ambiguous. The basher resembles the martial arts instructor who is the rescuer of the victim. Gesture and dance are used as a form of interior monologue exploring the way this act of violence resonates through the lives of the characters. “Beyond Gravity”: Richard spends his time fantasising about outerspace and the cosmos, an activity which antagonises friends and family. Then one day he meets Johnny, a handsome Italian man, with an enormous appetite for life, who offers him love and an escape from the monotony of work. This short New Zealand film is a joyous celebration of the love between two eccentrics. It is also a refreshingly matter-of-fact and comic treatment of a romance between two men who both have their sights aimed firmly amongst the stars.

results.title: Boys on film 1: Pool days. The Dead boys club
results.creator_credit: House of Pain Productions, Brian Sloan, Mary Weisgerber Meyer and Michael Christopher
results.brief_description: Two short American films about adolescent homosexual experiences. In “Pool days” (prod/dir: Brian Sloan), a young man begins work at a neighbourhood pool and dormant gay feelings are stirred being around nude, attractive men. In “The Dead Boys Club” (prod: Mary Weisgerber, dir: Michael Christopher) a young man goes to visit his cousin, whose lover has died from AIDS. When the young man puts on the dead man’s shoes he is transported into the disco era of the 1970s where sex and relationships were free of the fear of disease. These two films are light and joyous celebrations of queer life.

results.title: Boys in the age of machines
results.creator_credit: Academy Film Productions, Ronald Mason and Giorgio Mangiamele
results.brief_description: Presents the many opportunities available today in the field of engineering. Shows a typical machine-shop where a young apprentice follows the production of a pattern from the drawing board design to the casting being finished in the dressing shop. Outlines various diploma and degree courses; employment opportunities based on educational qualifications; preliminary subjects required in basic education.

results.title: Boys Grammar
results.creator_credit: AFTRS, Dean Francis, Justin Davies and Rozlyn Clayton-Vincent
results.brief_description:
Set in an exclusive boys school, Gareth learns that his feelings can be validated and expressed only through violence.
A graphic and disturbing look at the ritual of hazing.

results.title: Boys don't cry
results.creator_credit: Killer Films, Hart Sharp Entertainment, Jeffrey Sharp, John Hart, Eva Kolooner, Christine Vachon and Kimberly Pierce
results.brief_description: Based on the life and death of Brandon Teena, “Boys Don’t Cry” is a gripping and very moving account of difference and intolerance. Believing herself to really be a male, Brandon constructs a masculine persona for herself and acts and lives as a man in a poverty stricken community in Nebraska. Within this “white trash” locale she attempts to live her identity as best she can. She falls in love with Lana (Chloe Sevigny), a tender romance which results in a group of local young men venting their homophobic violence on the lovers. One of a series of works in late twentieth century American cinema which attempted to deal with the the increasing fracturing and alienation of working class life caused by unemployment and the rationalising of both economics and ethics, “Boys Don’t Cry” resonates deeply as both a story of damaged lives as well being an inspiring challenge to conservative understandings of gender and sexuality. Hilary Swank’s performance as Brandon justifiably won her an Academy Award for Best Actress, and Sevigny’s performance is equally fine. A labour of love for director Pierce, “Boys Don’t Cry” is an exemplary work of Queer Cinema, as well as an outstanding example of the best of American independent film.

results.title: Boys and girls
results.creator_credit: Atlantis Productions, Janice Platt, Seaton McLean, Michael Macmillan and Don McBrearty
results.brief_description: Set in the 1940’s on a fox farm, this film explores the critical period in a young girl’s life when she first realises the existence and implications of traditional role stereotyping. At thirteen, Margaret enjoys helping her father with the outdoor labour, but she soon realises that her parents consider her help necessary only until their son is old enough to take over. When her attempts to express her feelings fail and she sees the favoured treatment of her younger brother she rebels and lets loose a rogue mare destined for slaughter. Provides a valuable study of the subtle ways in which sex role stereotyping can occur. Based on a story by Alice Munro. Suitable for secondary school level.

results.title: Boys' game: Pushtu nomads
results.creator_credit: International Film Foundation and Hermann Schlenker
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Mountain peoples of Central Asia”.
Shows an ancient game, well-known in Asia, being played by Pushtu boys. Demonstrates the toughness of the young men and the value these tribal people place on physical superiority. Suitable for upper primary and lower and middle secondary levels.
